judgment.translation[0].definitions[0].d: an opinion that you form, especially after thinking carefully about something
judgment.translation[0].definitions[0].e: It’s too soon to make a judgment about what the outcome will be.
In my judgment, we should accept his offer.
I’d advise you to reserve judgment  (=not decide your opinion before you have all the facts).
Our aim is to help him, not to pass judgment on what he has done.
I lent him the money, against my better judgment.
judgment.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the ability to make sensible decisions about what to do and when to do it
judgment.translation[0].definitions[1].e: I’ve known him for years and I trust his judgment.
a decision based on sound judgment  (=good judgment)
Watch carefully and use your judgment.
The minister showed a lack of political judgment.
judgment.translation[0].definitions[2].d: an official decision given by a judge or a court of law
judgment.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The company were fined £6 million, following a recent court judgment.
judgment.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: It's too soon to make a judgment about what the outcome will be.

judgment.translation[1].definitions[0].d: an opinion formed or a decision made after careful thought
judgment.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Traders said they would wait to see more economic data before making a judgement about the economy.

judgment.translation[1].definitions[1].d: the ability to make good decisions
judgment.translation[1].definitions[1].e: There is no substitute for common sense and good business judgment.

judgment.translation[1].definitions[2].d: a decision made by a court of law
